article:
'expand' is a program that converts tab characters into groups of space
characters. It is available in Unix operating systems and many Unix-like
operating systems.

For example:

 $ echo -e "foo\tbar" | expand | xxd -g 1 -u 0000000: 66 6F 6F 20 20 20 20 20 62
 61 72 0A foo bar. $ echo -e "foo\tbar" | xxd -g 1 -u 0000000: 66 6F 6F 09 62 61
 72 0A foo.bar. $

Here the echo command prints a string of text that includes a tab character,
then the output is directed into the 'expand' command. The resulting output is
then displayed in hexadecimal and as characters by the 'xxd' dump command. At
the second prompt, the same echo output is sent directly to the xxd command. As
can be seen by comparing the two, the 'expand' program converts the tab
(specified as '\t' to the echo program) into spaces.
